content.description: The crux is at the last couple moves about 20 feet up, which is why this gets the "R" rating. Good hands provide some comfort at the high crux but fear sets in after pulling the move and before getting your feet up on the upper ledge....but at this point you've already traded comfort for fear.
content.location: Climb the central line of the western face of the boulder Comfort for Fear. Walk off the back side of the boulder carefully.

content.description: This is the right to left traverse using primarily topside, positive holds. It provides some pump coming down the left side of the boulder and ends with a sit finish. Just slightly harder than the L to R traverse because of its length.
content.location: Start at the undercling on the right side of the boulder behind the main face of Comfort for Fear boulder, moving up and left over the apex of the boulder and down the left side.

content.description: The upper rail offers good holds, while the face provides ample feet, making this is a fun traverse. The crux is finding your feet at the apex of the climb in order to reach solid topside jugs to top out.  Falling would be painful as the chasm is fairly deep (+/- 15 ft) and there's a large boulder behind you. Crash pads would do little good and spotters wouldn't fit in the chasm behind/below you, thus the PG13 rating.
content.location: This is the left to right traverse that follows the upper rail of the boulder behind Comfort for Fear.

content.description: This is the large, mostly west facing boulder to the south about 100 yards from the main uphill boulders (A-Frame and Javelina Cave). There are two boulders here separated by a crevice large enough to walk through about 20 feet high. The rock is of the same porous type as others found in this area and the faces provide some fun but R rated high ball problems and couple traverses on the backside boulder.
